article.title: Hubble Space Telescope Proper Motion (HSTPROMO) Catalogs of Galactic Globular Clusters. V. The rapid rotation of 47 Tuc traced and modeled in three dimensions

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the distribution of 47 Tuc stars in the Proper Motion (PM) diagram reveal about the cluster\'s dynamics?
choices: The PM distribution is identical in all four fields, indicating uniform kinematics.
The circular distribution in the central field indicates no rotation.
The flattening of the distribution in the inner and calibration fields suggests velocity-dispersion anisotropy.
The lack of background SMC stars in the inner field makes it difficult to assess cluster rotation.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded about the rotation of 47 Tuc in the plane of the sky by observing the systematic PM component of background SMC stars?
choices: SMC stars show no systematic PM component, indicating 47 Tuc is not rotating.
SMC stars appear to rotate counter-clockwise, implying a clockwise rotation of 47 Tuc in the plane of the sky.
SMC stars are not suitable reference objects for measuring cluster rotation due to their intrinsic motion.
SMC stars are distributed evenly across all PM diagrams, making it impossible to determine cluster rotation.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information do the color-magnitude diagrams (CMDs) provide in the context of studying 47 Tuc\'s rotation?
choices: The CMDs show no distinction between 47 Tuc stars and SMC stars, making it impossible to separate them.
The CMDs help isolate bona-fide SMC stars based on their distinct location compared to 47 Tuc stars.
The CMDs reveal that 47 Tuc stars are much fainter than SMC stars, making SMC stars ideal reference objects.
The CMDs are not useful for studying cluster rotation; they are only useful for determining cluster age and metallicity.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the general trend of the rotation profile of 47 Tuc in the plane of the sky (μΤΑΝ) as observed in this figure?
choices: The rotation profile steadily increases with increasing radius, suggesting a rigidly rotating system.
The cluster shows solid-body-like rotation within the central field, with the rotation profile flattening at larger radii.
The rotation profile is consistent with zero across all fields, indicating no significant rotation in the plane of the sky.
The measured rotation increases rapidly in the outermost regions, suggesting the presence of a massive perturber.
